item.description: Reuters - A top Vatican official said Tuesday he felt pity and compassion for Saddam Hussein and criticized the U.S. military for showing video footage of him being treated "like a cow."
item.title: Cardinal Says U.S. Treated Saddam 'Like a Cow' (Reuters)

item.description: Reuters - U.S. special envoy James Baker and French President Jacques Chirac agreed at talks Tuesday that their countries must cooperate over efforts to rebuild Iraq, Chirac's office said.
item.title: France, U.S. Agree Must Cooperate to Rebuild Iraq (Reuters)

item.description: Reuters - President Jacques Chirac is expected to announce a ban on wearing Muslim veils in French schools Wednesday in a speech aimed at reaching out to core conservative supporters three months before regional elections.
item.title: Chirac Seen Banning Muslim Veil in Key Speech (Reuters)

item.description: Reuters - Egyptian mediators returned to Gaza for a new round of talks with Palestinian factions Tuesday, but Israel ruled out a demand from militant groups that it must also guarantee any cease-fire.
item.title: Israel Rejects Truce as Mediators Return to Gaza (Reuters)

item.description: Reuters - Pakistani authorities suspect the hand of al Qaeda may be behind a weekend bid to assassinate President Pervez Musharraf, officials said Tuesday.
item.title: Pakistan Sees Al Qaeda Hand in Musharraf Murder Bid (Reuters)

item.description: AP - Chechen rebels who fought their way into the neighboring Dagestan region and occupied a village released all their hostages and fled, avoiding capture, Russian authorities said Tuesday.
item.title: Chechen Rebels Release Dagestan Hostages (AP)

item.description: AP - Israel will coordinate any unilateral moves in the West Bank and Gaza Strip with the United States, the Israeli foreign minister said Tuesday, after meeting with Bush administration officials who oppose any actions that will make it harder to create a Palestinian state.
item.title: Israel to Coordinate With U.S. on Moves (AP)

item.description: AP - Several dozen delegates broke away from a crucial constitutional assembly on Tuesday to celebrate the inauguration of the Kabul-Kandahar highway, a vital artery linking the capital with the lawless and poverty-stricken south.
item.title: Afghan Delegates Celebrate New Highway (AP)

item.description: AP - Rebel leaders said Monday they will release four Israelis and a Briton during the next several days, after holding the foreigners hostage in northern Colombia for three months.
item.title: Colombia Rebels Say They'll Free Tourists (AP)

item.description: Canadian Press - QUEBEC (CP) - A few thousand people demonstrated outside the Quebec legislature on Monday as Premier Jean Charest's government prepared to ram through legislation the union movement says hurts workers.
item.title: Thousands protest outside Quebec legislature against proposed labour laws (Canadian Press)

item.description: AP - The United Nations said Monday it was suspending for a month a disarmament campaign in war-battered Liberia so it can improve a camp for former combatants.
item.title: U.N. Suspends Disarmament in Liberia (AP)

item.description: AP - An Australian who became the first pilot to fly solo over the South Pole in a homemade plane flew back to New Zealand after being stranded on the ice for six days without fuel.
item.title: Pilot Reaches New Zealand After Stranded (AP)
